issue.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw: When I increase the mass of one of the links I also need to increase the number of iterations for a relatively noise-free force-torque sensor.
content.html: When I increase the mass of one of the links I also need to increase the number of iterations for a relatively noise-free force-torque sensor.

issue.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw:
In another thread I made a suggestion that it might be worth investigating adding filtering within a time step.  This noise seems to be due to simulator errors related to modeling of collision forces.

Let's say we use iters=50.  Applying a filter to the last 25 iterations might be more representative of "reality" than any single iteration.  At the next time step, the filter is re-initialized at the 25th iteration.

This may very well be a bad idea for any number of reasons, but has anyone considered it?
content.html:
In another thread I made a suggestion that it might be worth investigating adding filtering within a time step. This noise seems to be due to simulator errors related to modeling of collision forces.

Let's say we use iters=50. Applying a filter to the last 25 iterations might be more representative of "reality" than any single iteration. At the next time step, the filter is re-initialized at the 25th iteration.

This may very well be a bad idea for any number of reasons, but has anyone considered it?

issue.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw: Reducing priority, filtering helps for the wrist sensors if we don't care about fast signals.
content.html: Reducing priority, filtering helps for the wrist sensors if we don't care about fast signals.

issue.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw:
@DavidC:

I think we will hold off on filtering data in simulation and leave that to the users.

I briefly tested explicit residual filtering of `\Delta \lambda` after a few number of LCP iterations, but failed to find significant improvement to noise and seemed to have unpredictable effects to overall simulation stability.  Maybe implicit filter will do better?  but going down this road feels like a research project.  I'll hold off on this endeavour unless you find simultaneous improved simulation error reduction and un-degradaded stability?

Thanks,
John
content.html:
@DavidC:

I think we will hold off on filtering data in simulation and leave that to the users.

I briefly tested explicit residual filtering of \Delta \lambda after a few number of LCP iterations, but failed to find significant improvement to noise and seemed to have unpredictable effects to overall simulation stability. Maybe implicit filter will do better? but going down this road feels like a research project. I'll hold off on this endeavour unless you find simultaneous improved simulation error reduction and un-degradaded stability?

Thanks, John

issue.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw:
Here's the kind of velocity jitter I get with 50 iterations in my tests in qual 2 holding the drill, [see video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jjRqNG8zmE0).

This is done from [this gazebo branch](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/fe5c52791af6975d7d810be8a76326210088dd3f/?at=random_row_reordering) with [this sandia-hand branch](#!/osrf/sandia-hand/src/c120a66f87709585007558fb3626357e7336c4ee/?at=sim_contact_tuning).
content.html:
Here's the kind of velocity jitter I get with 50 iterations in my tests in qual 2 holding the drill, see video.

issue.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw: That is with damping = 30nm/rad/s I pressume? Lower damping probably inreases the jitter on the velocity, although I was referring to the force torque sensors here. I still think lower damping is desirable, to allow fast hand position changes to work in the driving task.
content.html: That is with damping = 30nm/rad/s I pressume? Lower damping probably inreases the jitter on the velocity, although I was referring to the force torque sensors here. I still think lower damping is desirable, to allow fast hand position changes to work in the driving task.

issue.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw:
Hi @jespersmith,

Here are the IMU plots:

  1. Here's the [grasping behavior with damping = 10nm/rad/s](http://youtu.be/uIDRqH3Lp5c) and
  1. Here again is [grasping with 30nms/rad again with imu values](http://youtu.be/lJfe8Kc41Zk).

The goal here is to achieve indefinite grasp-hold of the object at hand, but as demonstrated in first video, 10 nms/rad fails to do so.

John
content.html:
Hi @jespersmith,

Here are the IMU plots:

  1. Here's the grasping behavior with damping = 10nm/rad/s and
  2. Here again is grasping with 30nms/rad again with imu values.

The goal here is to achieve indefinite grasp-hold of the object at hand, but as demonstrated in first video, 10 nms/rad fails to do so.

John

issue.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw:
For the VRC, I am not sure indefinite grasp-hold is more useful than faster
finger movements. Which task needs indefinite grasp-hold against gravity?
Can't we just make sure the hand is always below the hose? The valve and and steering wheel aren't pulled away from the hand by gravity.
content.html: For the VRC, I am not sure indefinite grasp-hold is more useful than faster finger movements. Which task needs indefinite grasp-hold against gravity? Can't we just make sure the hand is always below the hose? The valve and and steering wheel aren't pulled away from the hand by gravity.

issue.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw: Grasp hold was mainly for task 3, it would be nice to be able to holding the fire hose without trying to keep the hand below the hose.  But at least for the [Q2 grasp example](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XiqNYr4H7XM), relaxing viscous damping by applying them adaptively appears to allow for faster finger motion (on the order of 2rad/s(F2) and 4rad/s(F1) when not holding an object).
content.html: Grasp hold was mainly for task 3, it would be nice to be able to holding the fire hose without trying to keep the hand below the hose. But at least for the Q2 grasp example, relaxing viscous damping by applying them adaptively appears to allow for faster finger motion (on the order of 2rad/s(F2) and 4rad/s(F1) when not holding an object).

issue.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw:
I just picked up the drill with our very simple controller (based on force control and velocity feedback for force distribution) and the robot has held the drill for at least 6 minutes simulation time now without the drill falling out of the hand. This is with the damping parameters for the fingers at 0.1 Nms/rad! 

So I think the high damping parameters are only necessary for the controller you used and I think the damping parameters should not be based on a controller implementation but on on real, measured values on the hand.
content.html:
I just picked up the drill with our very simple controller (based on force control and velocity feedback for force distribution) and the robot has held the drill for at least 6 minutes simulation time now without the drill falling out of the hand. This is with the damping parameters for the fingers at 0.1 Nms/rad!

So I think the high damping parameters are only necessary for the controller you used and I think the damping parameters should not be based on a controller implementation but on on real, measured values on the hand.

issue.title: Force Torque sensors are extremely noisy at iter=50, sor=1.4

content.raw:
Hi @jespersmith,
You are right, high joint damping values are indeed not necessary, 0.1 Nms/rad is stable with cfm damping, and behaves fine when the hand is not holding heavy objects.  However, we feel that 1.0 Nms/rad is a better approximation than current setting of 10.0 Nms/rad, while trading off faster finger movements for filtering out high frequency jitters in simulation.  Thoughts?
John
content.html: Hi @jespersmith, You are right, high joint damping values are indeed not necessary, 0.1 Nms/rad is stable with cfm damping, and behaves fine when the hand is not holding heavy objects. However, we feel that 1.0 Nms/rad is a better approximation than current setting of 10.0 Nms/rad, while trading off faster finger movements for filtering out high frequency jitters in simulation. Thoughts? John
